instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3024: What is 820-3024? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_MANUAL_RST_L: What is SMC_MANUAL_RST_L? SMC_MANUAL_RST_L resets the SMC when low.   _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.CPUIMVP_VR_ON: What is CPUIMVP_VR_ON? CPUIMVP_VR_ON is a signal that tells the buck converter responsible for PPVCORE_S0_CPU to turn on and create CPU vcore voltage. This comes from ALL_SYS_PWRGD â€“ once ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present, CPUIMVP_VR_ON will be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message:
Fan spins for a few seconds during which all S0 rails turn on but fall off after stopping. I've tried changing <CHIP>U2700</CHIP>, checked <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> current sense's. What should I be looking for at this point in terms of ****_PWRGD signals etc. aside from the <SIGNAL>S0_MAINS</SIGNAL> verified?

Questions:

1) When moving through voltage rails is one meant to check each associated "sub-rail"?
2) What is the proper voltage threshold for <SIGNAL>SMC_MANUAL_RST_L</SIGNAL>?
3) What is AXG core and why is it missing on functioning boards? What's the idea going on there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message:
What is the history for this board, water damage, dropped??
First the first, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stable and at what voltage, Do you have green light??
AXG is only present if internal display is present....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message: No traces of liquid or corrosion. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stable at 8.45v pp3v42 stable at 3.45v and green light present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message:
I get a short blip on mouse led as it powers on.

Voltage to ground on
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>  .295 (.482 on working board)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message:
Of course there is PP0V75 or there would be no fan spin...

Need history on the board, this usually does not just happen?

Vcore present on L7510 when fan spins?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message:
History is a guess aside from what I see which is lack of corrosion, no real discoloration of any probe points. Trace amounts of fruit punch(?) around the base of <CAPACITOR>C7119</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7120</CAPACITOR>; highly likely was cleaned before falling into my lap. it arrived naked in a lot which contained several broken screens with beat up corners maybe pulled from one of them after the accident?

Yes - VCORE at  L7510

L7330 v to ground .091 
(.113 on working board)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message: If Vcore is present then it could really be anything. Inspect for corrosion and/or knocked off components. Could also possibly be a corrupt BIOS, but that is pretty much the last option.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message: looking like a bios shot in the dark

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message: BIOS is the last thing that goes wrong on these. More likely knocked off components from being mishandled.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message:
Bios no go and  I may have ruined christmas.

I forgot that I borrowed <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> from <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_FB</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_FBA</SIGNAL>. Plugged in and got full fan spin (huh?) without them but cpu vcore was gone. by the time i realized my mistake an put them back, quarter turn returned and now missing cpu vcore. I'm assuming I killed <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> by running it without those resistors.. would that make sense?


IF... <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is dead, do i need to replace all mosfets along with it? I recall a video "why newbies suck at restoring vcore" stating replace everything together.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message: <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> never dies, more likely the CPU fried because there was no feedback and Vcore spiked high voltage. Another trash board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message:
Out of boredom/determination/sub-consious desire to waste time.?.? i circled back around to this one and it appears I mistakenly relayed inaccurate info.

CPU vcore IS indeed still present. Same symptoms, fan spins for 3 and stops without any signs of attempting to power cycle. during the 3 second spin up, I catch all S0 rails. I checked all <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> termination resistors and traces which are good.

Changed out <CHIP>U2700</CHIP> along with y2705 for lack of oscilloscope. Same response. I checked the end portion of the power on sequence as shown in the block diagram and found the following. 

<SIGNAL>PLT_RERST_L</SIGNAL>            0.16        (Assuming this one is out of spec?)

<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL>        3.3
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>        3.3    
<SIGNAL>CPU_PWRGD</SIGNAL>              1.05
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>                3.3
<SIGNAL>PM_MEM_PWRGD</SIGNAL>        1.5
L7100                         0.92
L7330                           1.5
L7630                          1.05
L7550                         0.79
L7510                          1.17

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>        3.3

I apologize if the response remains the same as Duke's prognosis above but wanted to swing this back by with the updated info and a bit of optimism before calling the game.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message: Forgot to add that if <SIGNAL>ON_OFF</SIGNAL> shorted and held for a bit the cpu gets warm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
threads.message: All that doesn't change anything. Vcore is present and the board is brain dead it could be anything. As this is a board with unknown history that has been in a pile of crap the chances of some component knocked off/cracked resistor. Anything and everything is now suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.. Quarter turn w/ all S0 rails present before full absence
